title: In Harry Potter, why did they use 7 potters if they can simply transform Harry into a letter and let his pet owl transport him? - Quora

response.answer_text: Because they can’t ‘simply’ do that and also the fact Harry would never in a million years go along with it. You can’t transform people into inanimate objects, doing this to Harry would likely kill him because a letter is so drastically different from a living human. Also, if you were gushing over the supposed brilliance of this idea, who here would actually want to be turned into a letter? You’d be rendered mute, deaf, blind and completely frozen, it all sounds extremely unpleasant and there’s a HUGE chance it’ll go horribly wrong. Harry would flat out refuse to allow himself to be rendered thus, even putting aside how horrifying the very idea is, he would hate being defenceless and unable to help his friends. And here’s something else no one has considered. In fifth year, when Harry was communicating with Sirius, Hedwig got attacked and the letter read. Meaning there’s a very good chance this plan would fail miserably as the Death Eaters would have no problem killing Hedwig and taking the letter. They would likely cast charms to see if anything was hidden and discover it’s Harry. It would then be a very simple thing to hand him over to Voldemort to kill. It’s an all round terrible idea.

Because you can’t transform people into letters. There are some charms that allow you to transfigure certain living creatures into other objects - such as the charm that turns mice into teacups from one of Harry’s early lessons - but these are very specific. Freeform transfiguration, while possible, doesn’t generally work on more… complicated things. Sure, you can turn one solid object into another, but you can’t generally transform living matter into other things this way. (If this sounds a bit hand-wavy, that’s because it is. Rowling’s rules of magic are somewhat erratic and often contradicted themselves later on. I imagine “mice into teacups” was the right note of whimsy early on as it’s clearly magic but it’s also completely ridiculous and useless.) One case to consider is in “Goblet of Fire”, in which Barty Crouch Jr is posing as Alastor Moody - for an entire school year! - and has the real Moody tied up in his own trunk. Wouldn’t it be easier to just transform him into something else? Barty does transfigure someone into a bone and bury him in the forest, but only after the man is already dead - so you could potentially turn Harry into a letter and post him if you didn’t mind him being a corpse first, but that would rather defeat the point!
